bestBHT.bht: When they had come into the boat, the wind grew weary and ceased, as if exhausted in the presence of its Master. This was another proof that the Son of God was with them. They worshipped him, acknowledging his divine power. The boat being immediately at the land where they were going could be attributed to either the wind driving them there or another miracle. The wind and sea obeyed Jesus, who is Lord of both.

Henry Alford: 32.] John (vi. 21) adds “and immediately the ship was at the land whither they went:’—see note there.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 32. And when they had come into the
boat, the wind ceased—(Also see on :-.)
Albert Barnes: He that has power over winds and waves has all power.
Another proof, amid this collection of wonders, that the Son of God was with them.
They came, therefore, and worshipped him, acknowledging him to be the Son of God.
Marvin Vincent: Ceased [εκοπασεν] . A beautiful word. Lit., grew weary; sank away like one who is weary.
Philip Schaff: John (John 6:21) speaks of the boat being immediately 'at the land whither they went.'
This was on the western side of the lake, and we may either suppose that the wind during the night had driven them near that shore.
Archibald T. Robertson: The wind grew weary or tired, exhausted itself in the presence of its Master.
Not a mere coincidence that the wind ceased now.
John Gill: The wind ceased: from blowing with that fury and violence it did before, and there was a perfect calm; which gave equal proof of the divine power of Christ, as his walking upon the sea."
He walked upon the sea whilst the wind was blowing hard, and the waves were tumultuous; he comes into the ship, and all is calm; both winds and sea obey him, who is Lord of both.

bhtAttempts.bht: When they had come into the boat, the wind grew weary and ceased, as if exhausted in the presence of its Master. This was not a mere coincidence, but another proof that the Son of God was with them. They came and worshipped him, acknowledging his divine power. John also speaks of the boat being immediately at the land where they were going, which could be attributed to either the wind driving them there or accepting another miracle. It is truly remarkable how the wind and sea obeyed Jesus, who is Lord over both.

They worshipped him, acknowledging his divine power. The wind and sea obeyed Jesus, who is Lord over both.

When they had come into the boat, the wind grew weary and ceased, as if exhausted in the presence of its Master. This was another proof that the Son of God was with them. They worshipped him, acknowledging his divine power. John also speaks of the boat being immediately at the land where they were going, which could be attributed to either the wind driving them there or another miracle. The wind and sea obeyed Jesus, who is Lord of both.

When they had come into the boat, the wind grew weary and ceased, as if exhausted in the presence of its Master. This was another proof that the Son of God was with them. They worshipped him, acknowledging his divine power. The boat being immediately at the land where they were going could be attributed to either the wind driving them there or another miracle. The wind and sea obeyed Jesus, who is Lord of both.

When the disciples finally made it back to the boat, the wind suddenly ceased, as if exhausted in the presence of its Master. It was not a mere coincidence that the wind ceased now; it was another proof that the Son of God was with them. In awe and reverence, they worshipped Him, acknowledging His divine power. John even adds that as soon as they entered the boat, they were immediately at the land they were headed to. This was either due to the wind driving them near that shore or another miracle of Christ. It is clear that the wind and the sea both obey Him, for He is the Lord of both.
